Hi @haria, 

I did this example for a fast-prototyping numerical test of mx-DDPG. So I'm sorry not to implement APIs for these functions.

To save the parameters, you have to pay attention to the four networks in ```ddpg.py```:

* ```self.qfunc_target``` (mxnet executor)
* ```self.policy_target``` (mxnet executor)
* ```self.policy``` (self-defined class)
* ```self.qfunc``` (self-defined class) 

For the two executors, call ```mx.nd.save``` to save the executor's ```arg_dict``` (and correspondingly ```mx.nd.load``` to load). For the self-defined classes, you might want to expose their executors to call ```mx.nd.save``` to save the ```arg_dict```.

To visualize the trainining process, basically, just call the env's internal method ```env.render()```. You might want to refer to [this](https://github.com/openai/rllab/blob/c226bd8e0ffa0c106f961d97285431d89b97e4de/rllab/sampler/utils.py#L30-L32) for a simple example.

Yes, the Tensorboard project only supports `scalar` and `histogram`, we need to support `image`, `video`, even `graph` and `embedding`. All the above are logging components.

There're other works to do beyond the logging, we're going to merge Tensorboard into MXNet, but currently users have to build it from scratch and make the whole installation too heavy(I'm not sure if it's acceptable). I was going to write a script to auto-build the wheel file using Travis-CI and user could install TensorBoard simply using `pip install tensorboard`, just like TF does. It needs some effects.
Besides, the logging part could be extended to other languages, as long as we have same logging format.

sudo R CMD INSTALL DiagrammeR_0.8.1.tar.gz

@piiswrong what I am trying to implement of mkl-dnn
what I am try to do is that
1. if input data is image data, mkl will allocate a operator buffer inside operator , transfrom image data to operator buffer, but write a private buffer to the output buffer inside NDArray , save some memory description in NDarray.
2. if the input data is NDArray , mkl will operator will try to use it
3. so the objective is that mkl will not store extra buffer in NDarray, only some memory description, and allocate buffer is use mxnet allocator

OK, I did a build using the Intel libraries for OpenCV, numpy, and MXNet, setting USE_MKL2017 to 1. As I increase the environment variable MKL_NUM_THREADS, I see CPU usage increase proportionately in both test, until it peaks at the number of physical cores on the machine. (Additionally changing MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS does not seem to have an additional effect, either on speed or CPU usage.) So, the Intel multithreading libraries appear to be working.

Once again, I see a substantial (183%) increase in speed for the numpy test, but only a 17% improvement in speed in the mxnet test. The cProfile results are similar (although MKL was a bit faster generally than OpenBLAS for the mxnet test on this machine). The vast majority of the time still appears to be spent in the NDArray.asnumpy() call:

       ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
            1    0.014    0.014    9.763    9.763 <string>:1(<module>)
            1    0.000    0.000    9.460    9.460 base_module.py:287(fit)
           21    0.000    0.000    9.155    0.436 module.py:521(update_metric)
           21    0.000    0.000    9.155    0.436 executor_group.py:413(update_metric)
           21    0.002    0.000    9.153    0.436 metric.py:134(update)
           42    9.147    0.218    9.149    0.218 ndarray.py:488(asnumpy)

Is there any other information that I can provide, or any other suggestions? Thanks!

I ran into this problem with the 0.8.0 release as well.  Rather than using a newer commit, I added the line `const int64_t GraphStorageAllocator::kBadStorageID;` as suggested by @xlvector into graph_memory_allocator.cc at line 10.

Here's a patch which does the same thing:
```diff --git a/src/symbol/graph_memory_allocator.cc b/src/symbol/graph_memory_allocator.cc
index bbec1e7..19b999f 100644
--- a/src/symbol/graph_memory_allocator.cc
+++ b/src/symbol/graph_memory_allocator.cc
@@ -7,6 +7,7 @@
 
 namespace mxnet {
 const uint32_t GraphStorageAllocator::kDummyColor = 1 << 31;
+const int64_t GraphStorageAllocator::kBadStorageID;
 
 GraphStorageAllocator::GraphStorageAllocator(
     StaticGraph *graph,
```

@ctongfei `init` (with `init-native`) detect the registered (c++) operators and use scala macros to generate op functions (in scala) automatically. `core` uses these generated functions.

From my point of view, one way to support CuDNN optimization is to enable multi-step forwarding (e.g add an argument in `__call__` called step_num or seq_len) in the RNNCell and add a flag in `__init__` to determine whether to use CuDNN . However, we will also need to add another operator to convert the biases and weights to the "parameter" in mx.sym.RNN.

Thx @piiswrong and @MichaMucha ,
I found a reslution for this problem just with two command lines in osx terminal:

locate ippicv
sudo ln -s /usr/local/share/OpenCV/3rdparty/lib/libippicv.a /usr/local/lib/libippicv.a

Also found another mistake in demo.py file Line 42 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rcnn/demo.py#L42
missing `need_mean=True` params, it should be,
`im_array = transform(im_array, config.PIXEL_MEANS, True)`
When it runs to Line 65, https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rcnn/demo.py#L65
it calls `transform_inverse` func and thus a mean value will be added to each image pixels.
But in `transform` func, the default value of `need_mean` is `False`

The same thing happened. On this card I get the poor performance too(max to about 45 samples/sec when training my own SSD example, while I get about 80 samples/sec on my first GTX750Ti).
I checked nvidia-smi of both GTX750Ti per second when training, and I found that the GTX750Ti with good performance showed stable volatile GPU-Util around 95%, but the one with bad performance showed quite a unstable volatile GPU-Util (ranged from 20% to 95%). Later I checked GTX1060 too, and its volatile GPU-Util ranged from 0% to 49%.
So it seems like there is something wrong in my latest cuda/mxnet environment built, not GTX1060's problem.

loader.py line 304 is just a typo.
demo.py line 42 need_mean = True. It is just that resnet does not need mean, p.s. I have used [0, 0, 0] as resnet image mean in later versions.
